docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''As Parents Age, Baby Boomers and Business Struggle to Cope'' (front page, March 25):

headline.main: Strains of Caring for Aging Parents

docs.abstract: Dr Bruce Leff letter says it is delusion to think that market will solve problem of long-term care for the elderly
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''As Parents Age, Baby Boomers and Business Struggle to Cope'' (front page, March 25):

docs.lead_paragraph: Critics who say the private insurance industry got too big a role in the new Medicare prescription drug program may not know the half of it. For patients, the program's rollout has had mixed reviews, with many happy customers but more than a few tales of woe. But for many big insurers, the new Medicare program is shaping up as a great opportunity. And prescription drugs may be only a starting point.

headline.main: A Benefit for Insurers; Medicare Drug Plan Feeds More Profitable Managed Care

docs.snippet: Critics who say the insurance industry got too big a role in the new Medicare drug program may not know the half of it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Providing insurance coverage for mental illness equal to that for physical illness does not drive up the cost of mental health care as many insurers feared, a new study says.

headline.main: Study Backs Equal Coverage for Mental Ills
headline.print_headline: Study Backs Equal Coverage For Mental Ills

docs.snippet: Providing insurance coverage for mental illness equal to that for physical illness does not drive up the cost of mental health care as many insurers feared, a new study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wanted: two people to help defend the nation's largest retailer against critics. Requirements: plenty of experience managing a crisis. Wal-Mart Stores has begun circulating two senior-level job postings -- both in public relations -- and if the language used to describe the positions is any indication, the giant discount retailer is on the P.R. equivalent of war footing.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Begins Quest For Generals In P.R. War

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores begins circulating senior-level public relations job postings--director of media relations and senior director of campaign management--for executives with plenty of experience managing crises; jobs reflect how much life has changed at Wal-Mart, which has come under withering attack over wages, health benefits and treatment of workers (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's largest retailer has begun circulating two senior-level job postings to help defend against critics.

docs.lead_paragraph: Setting off a fresh round of skirmishing over the budget on Wednesday, Gov. George E. Pataki's staff claimed that the Legislature's new budget understates spending by as much as $2.6 billion and would create deficits totaling at least $10 billion over the next two years. As if that were not enough, the governor's staff and the Legislature continue to squabble over whether the Legislature actually met the midnight Tuesday deadline for having their budget agreement printed in time for lawmakers to vote on it by Friday.

headline.main: With Ink Not Yet Dry on Budget, Pataki Aides Assail the Legislature's Plan

docs.abstract: Aides to Gov George Pataki claim Legislature's new budget understates spending by as much as $2.6 billion and will create deficits totaling at least $10 billion over next two years; sides do not agree on math or even whether budget was passed in timely fashion; focus of squabble is mainly on Medicaid, with Pataki citing Legislature's rejection of most of his cuts; charts; map (M)
docs.snippet: ALBANY, March 29  Setting off a fresh round of skirmishing over the budget on Wednesday, Gov. George E. Pataki's staff claimed that the Legislature's new budget understates spending by as much as $2.6 billion and would create deficits totaling at...

byline.original: By DANNY HAKIM; Jennifer Medina contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: HealthSouth, the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, said yesterday that its losses more than doubled in 2005 as it settled lawsuits stemming from a $2.7 billion accounting fraud. The net loss grew to $446 million, or $1.12 a share, from $174.5 million, or 44 cents a share, in 2004, the company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It was the fifth consecutive year of losses for HealthSouth. Revenue fell 8.7 percent, to $3.21 billion, hurt by stricter rules for payments from Medicare.
docs.abstract: HealthSouth says net loss in 2005 more than doubled, to $446 million, as it settled suits stemming from $2.7 billion accounting fraud; says revenue fell 8.7 percent, to $3.21 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Legislature agreed yesterday to require hospitals to give discounts to poor patients -- and even some middle-income people -- who have no health insurance. Hospitals have been criticized for charging more to treat uninsured patients than people who have coverage, and for not telling low-income patients when financial aid is available. The proposed law would bar those practices and set limits on charges to most uninsured people.

headline.main: Albany Acts On Behalf Of Patients Lacking Aid

docs.abstract: New York State legislators insert provision into budget bill to require hospitals to give discounts to poor and some middle-income patients who have no health insurance (M)
docs.snippet: The Legislature agreed yesterday to require hospitals to give discounts to poor patients  and even some middle-income people  who have no health insurance.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''It Isn't Amnesty'' (editorial, March 29):

docs.lead_paragraph: Caspar W. Weinberger, who held high positions under three Republican presidents and oversaw the biggest and costliest military buildup in peacetime history as Ronald Reagan's secretary of defense, died yesterday in Bangor, Me., after a brief illness. He was 88. Mr. Weinberger lived nearby in Mount Desert, Me. His son, Caspar Jr., also of Mount Desert, said his father had been undergoing kidney dialysis for two years and died of pneumonia. His wife of 63 years, Jane, was by his side when he died, his son said.

headline.main: Caspar W. Weinberger, Who Served 3 Republican Presidents, Is Dead at 88

docs.abstract: Caspar W Weinberger, who held senior positions under three Republican presidents and oversaw costliest military buildup in peacetime history, dies at age 88; photos (L)
docs.snippet: As Ronald Reagan's secretary of defense, Caspar W. Weinberger oversaw the costliest military buildup in peacetime history.

byline.original: By DAVID STOUT; Maria Newman contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors laid off several hundred white-collar workers on Tuesday, its latest move in a restructuring plan that is cutting deeply into all ranks of the company. Also on Tuesday, a top United Automobile Workers official said he expected the auto parts supplier Delphi to ask a bankruptcy judge to throw out its labor contracts Friday. Such a move would raise the likelihood of a strike at Delphi, which could cripple production at G.M.

headline.main: G.M. Lays Off Hundreds of White-Collar Employees

docs.abstract: General Motors lays off several hundred white-collar workers, latest move in restructuring plan; United Auto Workers vice president Richard Shoemaker, addressing union leaders in Detroit, says he expects auto parts supplier Delphi to ask bankruptcy judge to throw out its labor contracts; move would raise likelihood of strike at Delphi, which could cripple production at GM; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The G.M. layoffs are the latest move in a restructuring plan that is cutting deeply into all ranks of the company.
